qas.question: What British architect was responsible for designing much of New Delhi?
What are the names of the two central promenades around which New Delhi is structured?
Which of the two promenades is referred to as The King's Way?
Which promenade was formerly known as the Queen's Way?
The largest diplomatic enclave in India which contains 19 foreign embassies is located along which promenade?

context: Much of New Delhi, planned by the leading 20th-century British architect <a0_0>Edwin Lutyens<a0_0/>, was laid out to be the central administrative area of the city as a testament to Britain's imperial pretensions. New Delhi is structured around two central promenades called <a2_0>the <a1_0>Rajpath<a2_0/> and the Janpath<a1_0/>. The Rajpath, or King's Way, stretches from the Rashtrapati Bhavan to the India Gate. <a3_0>The Janpath<a3_0/> (Hindi: "Path of the People"), formerly Queen's Way, begins at Connaught Circus and cuts the Rajpath at right angles. 19 foreign embassies are located on the nearby <a4_0>Shantipath<a4_0/> (Hindi: "Path of Peace"), making it the largest diplomatic enclave in India.
